title: Paul Moriarty (rugby)
text:
William Paul Moriarty (born 16 July 1964) is a Welsh former international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer. He played rugby union for <a href="Swansea%20RFC">Swansea</a>, and represented <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a> before joining rugby league club <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a>, winning the <a href="1989%20World%20Club%20Challenge">1989 World Club Challenge</a>, and also representing <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>.
Moriarty later transferred from Widnes to <a href="Halifax%20R.L.F.C.">Halifax Blue Sox</a>, and represented <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales</a> in two <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">Rugby League World Cup</a>s. He later returned to rugby union, working in a number of different coaching roles and is employed as assistant coach at the <a href="Newcastle%20Falcons">Newcastle Falcons</a>. His older brother, <a href="Richard%20Moriarty">Richard</a>, also played rugby union for Swansea and Wales. Paul's son, <a href="Ross%20Moriarty">Ross Moriarty</a>, is also a professional rugby union player.
Background.
A second row or back row forward, Moriarty played rugby union for <a href="Swansea%20RFC">Swansea RFC</a>, and was in the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales squad</a> for the <a href="1987%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1987 Rugby World Cup</a>, helping Wales to third place and scoring a try in the 22–21 third place play-off victory over <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a>.
Professional playing career.
Moriarty changed <a href="rugby%20football">rugby football</a> codes from <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> to <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> when he transferred to champions <a href="Widnes%20Vikings">Widnes</a>. He was selected to play on the interchange bench for <a href="Widnes">Widnes</a> in their <a href="1989%20World%20Club%20Challenge">1989 World Club Challenge</a> victory over the <a href="Canberra%20Raiders">Canberra Raiders</a>. Moriarty also gained caps for the <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain Lions</a> against <a href="Papua%20New%20Guinea%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Papua New Guinea</a> in 1991 and <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">France</a> in 1994. He transferred from Widnes to Halifax for the <a href="1994-95%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1994-95 Rugby Football League season</a>, and was included in the <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Wales squad</a> for the <a href="1995%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1995 Rugby League World Cup</a>, he also played for <a href="South%20Wales%20RLFC%20%281995%29">South Wales</a> on loan.
Moriarty returned to rugby union when the code officially became professional and rejoined Swansea. A few years later following an injury crisis for the Welsh rugby league side's forward pack during the <a href="2000%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">2000 Rugby League World Cup</a>, 36-year-old Moriarty was recalled to the side.
After coach John Plumtree's departure in November 2001, Moriarty became <a href="player-coach">player-coach</a>, and, along with <a href="Tony%20Clement%20%28rugby%20player%29">Tony Clement</a>, ensured Swansea qualified for the 2002–03 <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> despite being fourth from bottom of the <a href="Welsh-Scottish%20League">Welsh-Scottish League</a> when they took over.
Coaching career.
The <a href="Introduction%20of%20regional%20rugby%20union%20teams%20in%20Wales">Introduction of regional rugby union teams in Wales</a> took place in time for the 2003–04 season, at which time Moriarty joined the <a href="Scarlets">Llanelli Scarlets</a> as forwards coach, becoming part of then-head coach <a href="Gareth%20Jenkins">Gareth Jenkins'</a> backroom staff. He remained at the club throughout the following tenures of <a href="Phil%20Davies">Phil Davies</a> and <a href="Nigel%20Davies%20%28rugby%20player%29">Nigel Davies</a>.
He became head coach of <a href="Welsh%20Premier%20Division">Principality Welsh Premiership</a> champions <a href="Cardiff%20RFC">Cardiff</a> for the 2009–10 season, and although the <a href="Cardiff%20Arms%20Park">Arms Park</a> club qualified for the playoffs despite only finishing seventh, they fell at the first hurdle to <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli</a>. On 21 May 2010, <a href="Guinness%20Premiership">Guinness Premiership</a> club Newcastle Falcons announced that they had appointed Moriarty as an assistant coach to his former Widnes teammate <a href="Alan%20Tait">Alan Tait</a>.
